awd_titl_txt: Women’s Political Participation in a Transitioning Democracy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF’s Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Rhacel Parreñas at the University of Southern California (USC), this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the role of women in politics during a democratic transition. Existing research on women’s political participation during democratic transitions generally concludes that women participate in revolutions and the early years of democratic transitions but stop shortly after. The United States,in particular, supports women political candidates and politicians, which likely improves their ability to remain politically active. Women politicians who get elected during democratic transitions deserve to be studied because they provide a model of increasing women’s political participation—not through political appointments, but rather through elections. The researcher will employ and train junior researchers to conduct policy-relevant research and communicate the research’s findings through written and oral policy briefings. 

Research on women’s long-term political participation during political transitions has tended to subscribe to one of two major sets of assumptions. First, much research assumes that women do not gain political influence beyond revolutions and the initial years of democratic transition. In contrast, the literature that argues that women become influential in the long term tends to focus exclusively on post-civil war contexts. Second, there is a growing scholarly literature on coalitions. Yet, much of the literature focuses on places where political actors form coalitions under relatively stable political conditions. Third, there are scholarly and activist debates about the role and impact of assistance during democratic transitions. Findings from this research can shed light on women’s political participation during democratic transitions and on coalition work across party lines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This qualitative research study examined the constitution of broad feminist alliances during uncertain times in deeply polarized societies. It also examined the role of global actors (Western international donors) in supporting those alliances. I did so by looking at the experiences of liberal/secular and conservative/Islamist women activists and politicians who cooperated during the democratic transition that followed the 2010-2011 Arab Spring in Tunisia over a decade (2011-2021). I also compared the behavior of Western international donors as coalition brokers in two broad feminist coalition attempts.

 

Of the five states that experienced the Arab Spring, Tunisia remained on the path to democracy the longest. This is in part because of women?s high political participation and active role in civil society, and foreign donor investment in the process. Women politicians cooperated to end political gridlocks, including finalizing the 2014 constitution when their parties refused to compromise. Women activists provided input on drafts of gender legislation. They helped women politicians secure bipartisan political buy-in for specific non-contentious issues like combatting violence against women and gender quotas. Building on my previous work, I interviewed international donors, implementers, and policymakers in New York, Tunisia, and Washington, DC. I supplemented the interviews with legal texts on gender policies that passed during the democratic transition and newspaper data on broad feminist cooperation in Tunisia during the same period.

 

One of my most significant findings is the emergent theme of the need to empower and listen to local partners. Broad feminist alliances that international actors facilitated succeeded only when international actors understood the local context, listened to their local partners, and selected non-contentious issues. Coalition attempts failed when donors attempted to impose practices from a universal broad coalition toolkit they developed based on other contexts. Because of their lack of awareness of the local context and unfamiliarity with local actors, they failed to bring conservative and liberal women to cooperate.

 

Moreover, I found that the success of broad feminist alliances should not be measured by how long they last. Instead, their success should be measured by the partners? ability to achieve their goals. In the Tunisian case, women activists and politicians worked across their political and ideological differences to pass one of the most progressive laws on combatting violence against women in the Arab world, a woman-friendly constitution, and comprehensive gender quotas.

 

Global actors, especially the United States, should continue to invest in Tunisia and the Arab Spring dream despite multiple incidents of backsliding on democracy in Tunisia. Global actors should continue to listen to their local partners and empower civil society. Local partners are risking their lives and doing the work on the ground to ensure Tunisia remains on the path to democracy. Global actors should continue to fund local organizations and work with the government of Tunisia to create a safe environment for women and civil society to function.

 

My findings extend beyond Tunisia and the Arab world. Feminists and politicians in mature democracies and emerging democracies alike could form broad feminist coalitions around non-contentious issues that benefit them and their constituents. The longevity of those alliances is less important than their ability to protect women?s existing rights during the rise of a global anti-gender backlash.

 


Last Modified: 09/15/2023
Modified by: Maro Youssef
